module.p: dé what is a question word (interrogative pronoun).

li.gd: Dé tha Seònaid a’ dèanamh anns an taigh? Tha i a’ cluich air an làr.
li.tr: What is Janet doing in the house? She is playing on the floor.

li.gd: Dé tha air an teine? Tha gual air an teine.
li.tr: What is on the fire? There is coal on the fire.

li.gd: Dé tha Seumas a’ dèanamh an diugh. Tha e ag obair gu trang anns an achadh.
li.tr: What is James doing today? He is working busily in the field.

li.gd: Dé tha ceàrr air a’ ghille seo? Tha a cheann goirt.
li.tr: What is wrong with this boy? His head is sore.

li.gd: Dé tha anns a’ bhocsa sin? Tha uighean anns a’ bhocsa.
li.tr: What is in that box? There are eggs in the box.
What is this? It’s a bottle.

li.gd: Dé tha air a’ chnoc? Tha taigh mór air a’ chnoc.
li.tr: What is on the hill? There is a big house on the hill.

module.p:
Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. [...] Dé na rudan a dh’ fhaodadh sinn iarraidh? Tuilleadh de luchd-teagaisg ’s de luchd-ceasnachaidh Gàidhlig. Airgead gu leabhraichean uallachadh is a chlo-bhualadh. Barrachd tìde air an réidio agus air telebhisean. [...]
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. [...] What are the things that we could demand? More Gaelic teachers and inspectors. Money to prepare and print books. More time on the radio and on television. [...] td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
[...] ’Se madainn bhòidheach foghair a bh’ ann—tioram, le ceileir eòin, is beagan dealt air an fheur. Bha a[m] muir ’s na tighean ag éirigh á inntinn an latha. Cha robh e fhéin a’ faireachdainn uabhasach math, oir, air a’ bhàta, bha triùir dhaoine le botul uisge-bheatha agus cha robh càil air a shon ach gu feumadh e òl ’nan cuideachd. “Dé ’n innleachd a th’ agad an sin?” arsa fear aca ris. “Clàr airson guthan,” fhreagair e, “tape-recorder.” [...]
[...] It was a beautiful autumn morning – dry, with the chirping of birds, and a little dew on the grass. The sea and the houses were rising from the mind of the day [??]. He was not feeling terribly good, because, on the boat, there were three men with a bottle of whisky and there was nothing for it but that he would have to drink in their company. “What is the machine that you have there?” said one of them to him. “A recorder for voices.” he replied, “a tape recorder.”[...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” “Carson nach do bhàsaich thu o chionn leth-cheud bliadhna,” dh’ éigh Màiri. Bha i smaoineachadh air na gnothaichean ud fhathast! “Greas ort leis an tea,” ars a màthair. Agus, mu dheireadh. “A’ chlann òga an diugh, chan eil fhios dé na smaointean th[a] ruith orra. Tha iad air bhoil, air bhoil.”
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” “Why did you not die fifty years ago,” shouted Mary. She was still thinking about those matters! “Hurry up with the tea,” said her mother. And, eventually. “The young children today, it is not known what thoughts are running on them. They are in a rage, in a rage.” td. 171, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
